Ready, Set, Learn!
You Need to Know
• How temperature sensors (e.g., thermistors or thermocouples) work and how they can be used to measure temperature changes.
• How to program the rover to make decisions based on sensor data.
• The basic structure of coding with "if-else" statements, loops, and conditionals.
You will be able to:
• Recognise the biological impact of radiation on living organisms, including its role in DNA damage and cell health. • Understand the relationship between temperature and radiation on Mars and how it affects rover behaviour.
• Code the rover to reroute when the temperature reaches dangerous levels, based on the data from the temperature sensor.

• Radiation on Mars can harm DNA and damage cell health. • Astronauts need rovers to explore the surface and mark areas of high radiation.
• Today, you will act like scientists testing shields and detectors to find out which areas are safe or unsafe. You have three identical yeast–sugar mixtures labeled: Control, UV-30s, and UV-120s. Each mixture is placed in a sealed bottle covered with a balloon or plastic wrap and kept in a warm environment. Every 15 minutes for one hour, measure the circumference of each balloon (in centimeters) to monitor gas production.

Hey friends let’s wrap up!
Radiation is powerful energy that can harm living organisms. It can damage DNA, which is like the “instruction book” inside every cell. When DNA is damaged, cells may not grow properly, may stop working, or even die. This is why astronauts need protection from high radiation on Mars.
• Radiation carries energy. When radiation (like sunlight or cosmic rays) hits a surface, it can transfer energy and cause the material to heat up.
• Areas with higher radiation often show higher temperature readings, while shaded or protected areas tend to be cooler. • On Mars, radiation is not always visible, but its effect can often be noticed in the temperature changes of the rover’s surroundings and equipment.
